questions.text: The most calorically dense macronutrient is _______
questions.solution:
Fat is the most calorically dense macronutrient providing approximately 9 kcal/g.

The nutrients that provide energy intake in the child’s diet are referred to as macronutrients. They include the following:

  1.  Fats (∼9 kcal/g)
  2.  Carbohydrates (4 kcal/g)
  3.  Proteins (∼4 kcal/g)

The main dietary sources of fat are as follows:

  • For infants: human milk/formula
  • For older children: fat from animal products, vegetable oils, and margarine.

questions.text: The mother of a school-going child is worried that he eats a lot of junk food. She is anxious to learn about the healthy diet to be followed in the child.  You would ideally advise the mother to restrict the dietary intake of saturated fat to less than ______  percentage of total energy intake.
questions.solution:
According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake.

Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents:

  • Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy
  • Saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy
  • Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day
  • No trans-fat

questions.text: Your school friend, the mother of a four-year-old child gives you a casual call. She had recently noticed an ad on margarine being a better alternative over butter/ghee and wishes to seek your opinion about adding it to her son's diet. What percentage of total daily energy requirement in children can come from margarine?
questions.solution:
Margarine and other hydrogenated oils are trans fat. Trans fat is not recommended in children according to current dietary guidelines.

 Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents:

  • Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy
  • Saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy
  • Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day
  • No trans-fat

questions.text: A newborn baby is ready to be discharged.  As a part of your discharge advice, for how many months would you recommend exclusive breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months. 

Complementary foods rich in iron and other micronutrients should be introduced at about 6 months of age. Breastfeeding should continue for at least the first year.

questions.text: You are taking a neonatal case for presentation during your postings. The mother tells you that the child is exclusively breastfed.  Which of the following is least likely to corroborate with this history of being exclusively breastfed?
questions.solution:
Exclusively breastfed infants are least likely to have evening colic. The incidence of diarrhoea, allergy to bovine milk, and atopic eczema are least reported in exclusively breastfed infants.

Option A: Vitamin K content of milk is low and may contribute to hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.

Option B: Breast milk contains inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase and enhances absorption of bilirubin from the gut. This leads to the development of breast milk jaundice. 

Option C: During the first few days, the breastfed infant has a black-green coloured stool. It changes to golden yellow by the end of the first week.

questions.text:
Which of the following mothers can initiate breastfeeding?
  1. A mother with an active infection of herpes on both her breasts.
  2. A mother with positive serology for hepatitis B infection.
  3. A mother with active tuberculosis.
  4. A mother who is on treatment with chemotherapeutic agents for leukaemia.
  5. A mother with a history of chronic smoking.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 2 and 5 only. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated if the mother has hepatitis B infection or if she is a chronic smoker.

Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother routinely receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin and hepatitis B vaccine. So, a delay in the initiation of breastfeeding is not required.

Contraindications of breastfeeding:

Do not Breastfeed

Do not give expressed breastmilk

Infant factors:

  • Classic galactosemia

Maternal factors:

  • Human T-cell lymphocyte virus (HTLV) infection
  • Ebola virus infection
  • PCP/cocaine abuse

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Do not give expressed breastmilk  (Temporarily)

Maternal factors:

  • Brucellosis
  • undergoing diagnostic imaging with radiopharmaceuticals
  • Active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection with lesions on the breasts

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Can give expressed breastmilk

Maternal factors:

  • Untreated, active Tuberculosis
  • Active Varicella infection

Alcohol consumption and smoking are NOT contraindications of breastfeeding. However, smoking and alcohol consumption should be discouraged.

Note: In a mother with untreated, active tuberculosis:

  • Temporarily withhold breastfeeding but can feed with expressed breastmilk
  • Resume breastfeeding once she has been adequately treated for 2 weeks and is no longer contagious.

WHO recommendations on breastfeeding in HIV infection:

  • Start mothers on antiretroviral therapy (ART)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months
  • Continue breastfeeding for at least 12 months, with the addition of complementary feeds.

questions.text: As a part of your neonatal rotation, you are asked to assess the adequacy of breastfeeding and breastfeeding techniques in a primi mother. Which of the following would be an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in the neonate?

choices.text: Baby sleeping for 2-3 hours after feed

questions.solution:
Weight loss of >7-10% of birth weight is an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in a neonate.

Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in the newborn:

  • Weight loss >7-10 % of birth weight
  • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours)
  • Delayed passage of stools (Less than 4 times/day)
  • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day)
  • Hypernatremic dehydration
  • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger

Insufficient milk intake may be caused by insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation.

Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed only on demand.

questions.text: For how long can freshly expressed breastmilk be stored at room temperature?
questions.solution:
Expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature for 6-8 hours.

Expressed breast milk

Stored for / Used within

(maximum time) 
Room Temperature 6 hours
In refrigerator 24 hours

Frozen breastmilk at -20°C

Note: This is a controversial question.

A difference of opinion among authors is noted regarding the refrigeration of expressed breast milk. Nelson's (21st ed, page 324) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 48 hours and frozen for around 6 months. However, AIIMS in collaboration with WHO recommends that breast milk can be refrigerated up to 24 hours and frozen at -20 degree C for about 3 months.

questions.text: Shrija, a working mother planning to resume her work wishes to know more about expressed breast milk. Within how many hours would you advise her to use the refrigerated expressed breast milk?
questions.solution:
Breast milk stored in the refrigerator should be used within 24 hours.

Refrigerated or frozen milk should be thawed rapidly by holding under running tepid water and used completely within 24 h after thawing. Milk should never be microwaved.

questions.text: An anxious new mother feeding her child with expressed breastmilk (EBM) feels that the consistency and colour of her milk have changed recently. She adds that when she expresses breastmilk, the colour and consistency of the first portion and the ending portion is completely different and that she is worried about the same.  Which statement is not true about different breast milk?

choices.text: Mature milk is thicker with all the essential nutrients for growth
Foremilk is watery and is rich in proteins and sugar
Hindmilk is richer in fat and provides more energy

questions.solution:
Mature milk is thinner (not thicker) with all essential nutrients for growth.

Various transitional forms of breastmilk:

Colostrum

  • In the initial 3 to 4 days
  • Small quantity, thick, and yellow in colour
  • A large number of antibodies, immune component cells; and vitamins A, D, E, and K.

Transitional milk

  • Secreted after 3 to 4 days until 2 weeks
  • Immunoglobulin and protein content decreases, while the fat and sugar content increases.

Mature milk

  • Follows transitional milk.
  • Thinner and more watery.
  • Contains all the nutrients essential for the optimal growth of the baby. 

Foremilk

  • Secreted at the start of the feed
  • Watery and rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water that quenches the baby’s thirst.

Hindmilk 

  • Comes towards the end of the feed
  • Provides more energy and a sense of satiety and it is richer in fat.

Preterm milk 

  • Milk of mother who delivers before 37 weeks.
  • Contains more proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobins, and calories as per the requirement of the preterm infant.

The given image shows watery foremilk and hindmilk which is rich in fat.

questions.text: Following the delivery of a healthy baby boy, his COVID positive mother slipped into ARDS and passed away. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image.  In newborns of which gestational age, would you recommend this as a method of primary feeding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to your OPD with complaints of diarrhoea. The mother wants to know if she should continue breastfeeding. Which of these components in breast milk, beneficial in intestinal cell maturation and repair, prompt you to advise her to continue breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
The epidermal growth factor present in breastmilk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair. This is why mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding in an infant affected with diarrhoea. It is also beneficial in luminal surveillance.

Lactoferrin (Option A) helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, antimicrobial action. It is also an antiadhesive and trophic for intestinal growth. 

Para-aminobenzoic acid (Option C) is present in low levels and offers protection against plasmodium. 

Glutathione peroxidase (Option D) prevents lipid oxidation. 

World Breastfeeding Week is held annually from August 1 to 7 and is supported by WHO, UNICEF, and health ministries. The theme of this year is "Closing the gap: Breastfeeding support for all" - highlighting the importance of recognising and supporting breastfeeding mothers, sharing experiences, and promoting multi-level support through policies, building a breastfeeding-friendly healthcare system, respect for women's autonomy, and community solidarity.

questions.text:
A young working mother wants to add formula feeds to the diet of her 5-month-old child as she would be unable to breastfeed her baby frequently and satiate her. Which of the following fatty acid should the mother look for in the formula to ensure optimal brain development in the child?
  1. Eicosapentanoic acid
  2. Docosahexaenoic acid
  3. Arachidonic acid
  4. Linolenic acid
questions.solution:
Docosahexenoic acid (DHA) and arachidonic acid (ARA), both play an important role in the growth and CNS development in babies.

DHA and ARA are essential poly unsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) present in breast milk.

Both are essential for cognition functions, visual acuity, and immune responses. They have optimal effects on brain development when included together, in efficacious levels, in an infant's diet.

Almost all infant formulae are now fortified with pre-formed DHA and ARA.

It is advisable that all infants upto 6 months of age are to be exclusively breastfed and not formula fed. However, in unavoidable situations such as lactation failure or maternal infections where breastfeeding is contraindicated, the use of a formula feed that contains both DHA and ARA is recommended. 

Other options:

  • Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and Linolenic acid are other essential fatty acids that are present in breast milk.
  • These are required for the overall protection of the cardiovascular system as well as to reduce systemic inflammation.

questions.text: Breast milk is superior to cow’s milk because ________

choices.text: Casein is 60% of the protein content
Whey is 70% of the protein content

questions.solution:
Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The Whey: Casein ratio in human milk fluctuates between 70:30 and 80:20. This ratio is 20:80 in cow's milk. The high fraction of soluble whey protein in breast milk makes it easily digestible.

The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk. Human milk contains amino acids like taurine and cysteine (lacking in cow’s milk), which are necessary for neurotransmission and neuromodulation.

Breast milk is rich in polyunsaturated fat (not saturated fat), which is necessary for myelination. Human breast milk is generally rich in oleic acid and linoleic acid.

Sodium concentration is not high in breast milk. It has a low osmolality, and hence, the solute load on the kidneys is low.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools are yellow and urine appears pale straw, he is otherwise well. A provisional diagnosis of breastmilk jaundice is made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Some babies need treatment with phototherapy
It is common in the second week of life

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Breastmilk jaundice is seen in about 2–4% of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding. 

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

It is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth). It is due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. The treatment would include continuing breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

"We haven't stopped breastfeeding even once for treatment of breast milk jaundice in the last 15 years!" states the AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology-2019 (2nd edition; Page no -231)

questions.text: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with fever and pain in her left breast. She has had difficulty with breastfeeding previously, and now examination reveals her left breast is warm, red, swollen, and painful to palpation. She was started on dicloxacillin. What advice should be given to the mother regarding breastfeeding?

choices.text: Continue feeding from both the breasts
Continue feeding from only right breast
Continue feeding from only left breast

questions.solution:
Lactational mastitis is not a contraindication to breastfeeding and the mother should continue feeding on both breasts.

It is most commonly caused due to Staphylococcus aureus present in the infant's nasopharynx. Dicloxacillin is safe to be given in nursing mothers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true with respect to the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

choices.text: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge
Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants with immature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.solution:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period of time. 

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It is economic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. 

Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It requires frequent replacement.

Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a risk of aspiration.

World Breastfeeding Week is a global campaign celebrated 1-7 August every year. World Breastfeeding Week aims to highlight the benefits that breastfeeding can bring to both the health and welfare of babies, as well as for maternal health. The theme for the year 2022 is "Step Up for Breastfeeding: Educate and Support".
